Line 1: Line 1:   +
{{current}}
'''Lubna Ahmed al-Hussein''' is a prominent [[Sudan]]ese female journalist<ref name="sd0">{{cite web| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/07/sudanese-journalist-taken-to-court-for-sensational-clothing.html| title= SUDAN: Female journalist faces 40 lashes for choice of clothes|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> who also worked for the media department of the [[United Nation|UN]] mission in [[Sudan]].<ref name="sd">{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/jul/31/inpraiseof-lubna-hussein-sudan|publisher=guardian.co.uk| title= In praise ofâ¦ Lubna Hussein|accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref> Known for her public criticism of the regimeâs oppression of women in Sudan, Lubna al-Hussein came to the focus of the [[news media]] when she was arrested on [[July 3]], 2009 with 13 other women for wearing a [[blouse]] and [[trousers]].<ref name="sd3">{{cite web| url=http://www.msmagazine.com/news/uswirestory.asp?ID=11850| title=Journalist Goes to Trial in Sudan Flogging Case|publisher= [[Feminist Majority Foundation]]|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> Such action is considered a ''threat to the Sudanese society values and virtues'' by the 1991 Sudanese law. She was sentenced to 40 lashings<ref name="sd1">{{cite web | url=http://www.euroweeklynews.com/2009071360115/news/international/journalist-lubna-ahmed-al-hussein-faces-40-lashings-for-wearing-trousers.html| title=JOURNALIST LUBNA AHMED AL-HUSSEIN FACES 40 LASHINGS FOR WEARING TROUSERS|publisher=Euro Weekly News Media Group|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> but was refused a plea bargain that would have limited her punishment to 10 lashes. She also resigned from her job as a journalist working for the UN mission, which grants immunity of its employers, knowing that if she lost her case, the penalty could be 40 lashes.<ref name="sd"/>
'''Lubna Ahmed al-Hussein''' is a prominent [[Sudan]]ese female journalist<ref name="sd0">{{cite web| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/07/sudanese-journalist-taken-to-court-for-sensational-clothing.html| title= SUDAN: Female journalist faces 40 lashes for choice of clothes|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> who also worked for the media department of the [[United Nation|UN]] mission in [[Sudan]].<ref name="sd">{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/jul/31/inpraiseof-lubna-hussein-sudan|publisher=guardian.co.uk| title= In praise ofâ¦ Lubna Hussein|accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref> Known for her public criticism of the regimeâs oppression of women in Sudan, Lubna al-Hussein came to the focus of the [[news media]] when she was arrested on [[July 3]], 2009 with 13 other women for wearing a [[blouse]] and [[trousers]].<ref name="sd3">{{cite web| url=http://www.msmagazine.com/news/uswirestory.asp?ID=11850| title=Journalist Goes to Trial in Sudan Flogging Case|publisher= [[Feminist Majority Foundation]]|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> Such action is considered a ''threat to the Sudanese society values and virtues'' by the 1991 Sudanese law. She was sentenced to 40 lashings<ref name="sd1">{{cite web | url=http://www.euroweeklynews.com/2009071360115/news/international/journalist-lubna-ahmed-al-hussein-faces-40-lashings-for-wearing-trousers.html| title=JOURNALIST LUBNA AHMED AL-HUSSEIN FACES 40 LASHINGS FOR WEARING TROUSERS|publisher=Euro Weekly News Media Group|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> but was refused a plea bargain that would have limited her punishment to 10 lashes. She also resigned from her job as a journalist working for the UN mission, which grants immunity of its employers, knowing that if she lost her case, the penalty could be 40 lashes.<ref name="sd"/>
